class=\"dottedline\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb0\">several algorithms have been developed to predict the pathogenicity of single nucleotide variants (\u003ca href=\"#b61\">macarthur et al., 2014\u003c/a>). these algorithms are used in conjunction with variant frequency data from case cohorts and reference population databases, such as gnomad, bravo, and regeneron (\u003ca href=\"#b50\">karczewski et al., 2020\u003c/a>). to further assess the potential pathogenicity of \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> vus associated with gbr-related disorders, we used three \u003cem>in silico\u003c/em> prediction tools: revel (\u003ca href=\"#b44\">ioannidis et al., 2016\u003c/a>), cadd (\u003ca href=\"#b53\">kircher et al., 2014\u003c/a>), and alphamissense (\u003ca href=\"#b16\">cheng et al., 2023\u003c/a>). scores for revel, cadd and alphamissense were obtained from the dbnsfp database (\u003ca href=\"https://www.dbnsfp.org/\">https://www.dbnsfp.org/\u003c/a>) and compared to those of known pathogenic variants (\u003ca href=\"#f4\">figure 4\u003c/a>). the results show that all three tools reliably classify the majority of known pathogenic variants as deleterious. notably, many \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> vus linked to gbr-related disorders also received high pathogenicity scores, suggesting they may be disease-causing.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"imageheaders\">figure 4\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"figuredesc\">\r\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-g004.jpg\" name=\"figure4\" target=\"_blank\">\r\n\n \u003cpicture>\n \u003csource type=\"image/webp\" srcset=\"https://images-provider.frontiersin.org/api/ipx/w=480&f=webp/https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-g004.jpg\" media=\"(max-width: 563px)\">\u003csource type=\"image/webp\" srcset=\"https://images-provider.frontiersin.org/api/ipx/w=370&f=webp/https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-g004.jpg\" media=\"(max-width: 1024px)\">\u003csource type=\"image/webp\" srcset=\"https://images-provider.frontiersin.org/api/ipx/w=290&f=webp/https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-g004.jpg\" media=\"(max-width: 1441px)\">\u003csource type=\"image/webp\" srcset=\"https://images-provider.frontiersin.org/api/ipx/w=410&f=webp/https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-g004.jpg\" media=\"\">\u003csource type=\"image/jpg\" srcset=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-g004.jpg\" media=\"\"> \u003cimg src=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-g004.jpg\" alt=\"www.frontiersin.org\" id=\"f4\" loading=\"lazy\">\n \u003c/picture>\n\r\n\u003c/a>\r\n\u003cp>\r\n\u003cb>figure 4\u003c/b>. computational pathogenicity prediction scores for missense variants listed in clinvar (source: dbnsfp v.5.1). variants were assessed using the cadd, revel and alphamissense prediction tools. data are shown as violin plots, with the median (solid black line) and the first and third quartiles (dotted lines) indicated. for comparison, the scores of pathogenic/likely pathogenic variants from \u003ca href=\"#t2\">tables 2\u003c/a>,\u003ca href=\"#t3\">3\u003c/a> (\u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em>) are shown on the right, with their median values marked. the scores for each of these variants are provided in \u003ca href=\"#t2\">tables 2\u003c/a>,\u003ca href=\"#t3\">3\u003c/a>. dashed horizontal lines denote the deleteriousness thresholds specific to each prediction tool, above which variants are predicted to affect protein function and are thus considered potentially pathogenic.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"clear\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb0\">pathogenic variants in \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> are commonly associated with a clinical phenotype that includes neurodevelopmental delay and/or epilepsy (\u003ca href=\"#b15\">cediel et al., 2022\u003c/a>). affected individuals typically present with early motor delays, speech and language impairments, id, learning difficulties, and/or behavioral abnormalities. this phenotypically heterogeneous neurological disorder, caused by monoallelic \u003cem>de novo\u003c/em> missense \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em>, is designated as nedlc. pathogenic variants in \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> were initially identified in individuals with dee59 (\u003ca href=\"#b24\">euro et al., 2014\u003c/a>) or with clinical features resembling atypical rett syndrome (\u003ca href=\"#b59\">lopes et al., 2016\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b103\">vuillaume et al., 2018\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b109\">yoo et al., 2017\u003c/a>). individuals with the latter presentation are now more accurately diagnosed with ndplhs. this condition is characterized by developmental stagnation or regression in early childhood, typically manifesting as loss of purposeful hand movements, impaired or lost language abilities, and id. since these initial reports, additional pathogenic \u003cem>de novo\u003c/em> mutations in \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> have been discovered in cohorts of individuals with id (\u003ca href=\"#b14\">carneiro et al., 2018\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b20\">deciphering developmental disorders, 2017\u003c/a>), asd (\u003ca href=\"#b2\">al-sarraj et al., 2021\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b90\">takata et al., 2018\u003c/a>), and drug-resistant epilepsy (\u003ca href=\"#b52\">kim et al., 2021\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b80\">rochtus et al., 2020\u003c/a>). notably, the recurrent \u003cem>de novo\u003c/em> missense variant \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> p.ala567thr, which affects a highly conserved residue within the third transmembrane helix (tm3), has been identified in more than 10 unrelated individuals presenting with ndplhs.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb0\">while computational predictions are valuable for assessing the potential pathogenicity of variants, functional studies are essential to determine their impact on protein function, including whether they cause gof or lof effects and to what extent these alterations influence receptor activity. furthermore, functional studies help elucidate molecular disease mechanisms&#x02014;an essential step toward accurate diagnosis and the development of targeted therapies. cell-based assay systems that enable direct and selective measurement of gbr activity have proven to be both cost-effective and highly informative for functionally characterizing missense variants in \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> (\u003ca href=\"#b8\">bielopolski et al., 2023\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b15\">cediel et al., 2022\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b103\">vuillaume et al., 2018\u003c/a>). these analyses have revealed a number of functional alterations in pathogenic variants, which may also occur in combination: (i) reduced or absent surface expression, leading to decreased or abolished gaba efficacy at the receptor; (ii) a significant reduction in the potency of gaba at the receptor; and (iii) increased constitutive activity. a reduction in surface expression is observed for several pathogenic variants in \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em>, which can be located either in the extracellular vftd or within the tmd. notably, \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> p.gly673asp in tm3 and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> p.gln430pro in the vftd fail to reach the cell surface, rendering the receptors completely inactive. a decrease in gaba potency is observed at \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> p.glu368asp and p.ser321leu, both situated in the vftd near the orthosteric binding site. these variants likely decrease the receptor&#x02019;s affinity for gaba. increased constitutive activity is predominantly associated with variants located in the tmds of gb1 and gb2. specifically, \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> p.ile809ser and p.ile847val, along with \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> p.ala567thr, p.ser695ile, p.met702val, p.ile705asn, and p.ala707thr, all exhibit enhanced constitutive activity to varying degrees. constitutive activity in these variants is reversed by the competitive gbr antagonist cgp54626, except for p.ser695ile, which is fully active in the absence of gaba (\u003ca href=\"#b103\">vuillaume et al., 2018\u003c/a>). structural mapping of these variants onto available gbr models reveals their localization along the tmds (\u003ca href=\"#f3\">figure 3\u003c/a>). structural data suggest that amino acid substitutions within the tmds can stabilize the active state of gb2, thereby enabling g protein activation even in the absence of gaba binding (\u003ca href=\"#b58\">liu et al., 2021\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b86\">shaye et al., 2021\u003c/a>). increased constitutive activity is also observed with variants in the vftds. molecular dynamics simulations suggest that \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> p.gly531ser, located in a hinge region outside the orthosteric binding site, and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> p.arg212gln, situated in the vftd, both induce local conformational changes that stabilize the active state of the receptor. this aligns with the allosteric activation mechanism of gbrs, in which agonist binding to the vftd of gb1 induces conformational changes transmitted to the tmd of gb2, ultimately activating the g protein (\u003ca href=\"#b86\">shaye et al., 2021\u003c/a>). notably, due to their elevated baseline activity in the absence of gaba, all constitutively active variants exhibit a corresponding reduction in gaba efficacy. the \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> variant p.gly110ala, situated in sd2, has not yet been functionally characterized, but may selectively impair the function of presynaptic gbrs. overall, functional studies have revealed both lof and gof variants in \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em>.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb0\">the \u003cem>in vivo\u003c/em> effects of constitutively active variants are likely to be complex and context-dependent. under conditions of low ambient gaba, constitutive activity and increased gaba potency may enhance gbr signaling, producing a gof effect. in contrast, during periods of elevated synaptic gaba concentrations, reduced gaba efficacy could lead to a net lof. while inverse agonists can suppress constitutive receptor activity, they risk further dampening gaba-mediated signaling during synaptic transmission, potentially exacerbating functional deficits. functional studies in transfected neurons suggest that certain constitutively active \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> variants disrupt receptor trafficking to the neuronal surface, resulting in reduced signaling efficacy and contributing to presynaptic hyperexcitability (\u003ca href=\"#b66\">minere et al., 2024\u003c/a>). notably, this synaptic phenotype was reversed by pharmacological enhancement of gbr signaling using a pam. moreover, variants such as \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> p.ser695ile, which exhibit high constitutive activity, may trigger adaptive cellular mechanisms that ultimately downregulate receptor function. these observations underscore the challenge of selecting an optimal therapeutic strategy based solely on \u003cem>in vitro\u003c/em> data, emphasizing the need for a deeper understanding of variant-specific effects in a physiological context. the advent of crispr/cas genome editing has made it relatively rapid and cost-effective to generate mouse models carrying specific variants inserted into the endogenous gene locus. such models closely replicate the human condition by maintaining physiological expression levels within the native neuronal environment&#x02014;a critical factor when studying monoallelic variants. these models offer a powerful platform for detailed investigations of synaptic and network function through both \u003cem>in vitro\u003c/em> and \u003cem>in vivo\u003c/em> electrophysiology. in parallel, they enable comprehensive biochemical profiling of the receptor and its signaling partners, facilitating the identification of adaptive or compensatory mechanisms that may emerge in response to altered receptor function.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb0\">interestingly, both lof and gof variants can give rise to overlapping clinical phenotypes (\u003ca href=\"#t4\">table 4\u003c/a>). as noted above, gof effects driven by constitutive receptor activity are accompanied by a reduced responsiveness to synaptic gaba, effectively resulting in a concomitant lof. in addition, both types of variants may disrupt homeostatic mechanisms critical for maintaining neural network stability and the balance between excitation and inhibition (\u003ca href=\"#b100\">vertkin et al., 2015\u003c/a>). such disruption likely contributes to the etiology of neurological and psychiatric disorders, including epilepsy, id, and asd (\u003ca href=\"#b45\">issa et al., 2023\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b107\">wondolowski and dickman, 2013\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"imageheaders\">table 4\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"figuredesc\">\r\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-t004.jpg\" name=\"table4\" target=\"_blank\">\r\n\n class=\"clear\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003ca id=\"h5-3\" name=\"h5-3\">\r\n\u003c/a>\r\n\u003ch3 class=\"pt0\">4.3 \u003cem>ajap1\u003c/em> variants\u003c/h3>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb0\">proteomic analyses of brain tissue have identified ajap1 as a primary interaction partner of gbrs (\u003ca href=\"#b85\">schwenk et al., 2016\u003c/a>). ajap1 is a single-pass transmembrane protein broadly expressed in neurons, with its extracellular domain binding to sd1 of gb1a (\u003ca href=\"#f1\">figure 1a\u003c/a>) (\u003ca href=\"#b21\">dinamarca et al., 2019\u003c/a>). through this interaction, ajap1 trans-synaptically recruits gb1a-containing gbrs to presynaptic sites, thereby influencing their synaptic localization and function (\u003ca href=\"#f1\">figure 1b\u003c/a>) (\u003ca href=\"#b30\">fruh et al., 2024\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb0\">genetic variants in genes encoding gbr-associated proteins, such as ajap1, may contribute to diseases resulting from gbr dysfunction. gwas studies have implicated non-coding \u003cem>ajap1\u003c/em> variants in insomnia and dementia (\u003ca href=\"#t1\">table 1\u003c/a>). wes and chromosomal microarray analysis have identified individuals carrying either the \u003cem>ajap1\u003c/em> missense variant p.trp183cys, the frameshift variant p.i271ffs&#x0002a;24, the splice-site variant c.917 &#x0002b; 1g&#x0003e;c, or a complete deletion (\u003ca href=\"#t5\">table 5\u003c/a>) (\u003ca href=\"#b30\">fruh et al., 2024\u003c/a>). these individuals predominantly present with global developmental delay, id, hypotonia, and/or epileptic seizures. these clinical features closely resemble those reported in individuals with lof variants in \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> (\u003ca href=\"#t2\">table 2\u003c/a>) (\u003ca href=\"#b15\">cediel et al., 2022\u003c/a>), indicating that impaired gbr function may contribute to the underlying pathogenesis. the \u003cem>de novo\u003c/em> ajap1 variant p.trp183cys replaces a critical tryptophan at position 183 that is essential for sd1 binding. the \u003cem>de novo\u003c/em> p.i271ffs&#x0002a;24 frameshift variant may trigger nonsense-mediated mrna decay. however, any transcript escaping decay is expected to produce a truncated protein lacking the transmembrane and intracellular domains, while retaining the sd1 binding site. a paternally inherited complete \u003cem>ajap1\u003c/em> deletion results in lof. the splice-site variant c.917 &#x0002b; 1g&#x0003e;c is predicted to disrupt normal splicing, potentially leading to nonsense-mediated decay, exon skipping, activation of a cryptic splice site, or intron retention.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"imageheaders\">table 5\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"figuredesc\">\r\n\u003ca class=\"clear\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb0\">to strengthen a causal link between the p.trp183cys variant and gbr dysfunction, mice carrying the orthologous \u003cem>ajap1\u003c/em> p.trp183cys variant were generated. heterozygous \u003cem>ajap1\u003c/em>\r\n\u003csup>trp183cys/&#x0002b;\u003c/sup> mice mimic the monoallelic p.trp183cys genotype observed in patients, enabling the investigation of gbr dysfunctions in the brain. ultrastructural analysis revealed a significant reduction in presynaptic gbr levels in \u003cem>ajap1\u003c/em>\r\n\u003csup>trp183cys/&#x0002b;\u003c/sup> mice, demonstrating that replacement of tryptophan 183 impairs ajap1&#x02019;s ability to recruit gbrs to synaptic terminals (\u003ca href=\"#f5\">figure 5\u003c/a>). as a consequence, \u003cem>ajap1\u003c/em>\r\n\u003csup>trp183cys/&#x0002b;\u003c/sup> mice exhibited reduced gbr-mediated presynaptic inhibition at both excitatory and inhibitory synapses, along with impaired synaptic plasticity. similar synaptic deficits were observed in \u003cem>ajap1\u003c/em>\r\n\u003csup>&#x02212;/&#x0002b;\u003c/sup> mice, which model the heterozygous deletion of \u003cem>ajap1\u003c/em> seen in patients. both \u003cem>ajap1\u003c/em>\r\n\u003csup>trp183cys/&#x0002b;\u003c/sup> and \u003cem>ajap1\u003c/em>\r\n\u003csup>&#x02212;/&#x0002b;\u003c/sup> mice thus phenocopy the synaptic impairments reported in \u003cem>gb1a\u003c/em>\r\n\u003csup>&#x02212;/&#x02212;\u003c/sup> mice, which lack presynaptic gbrs (\u003ca href=\"#b101\">vigot et al., 2006\u003c/a>). individuals with heterozygous lof alleles in \u003cem>ajap1\u003c/em> therefore represent the first clinical cases of presynaptic gbr dysfunction.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"imageheaders\">figure 5\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"figuredesc\">\r\n\u003ca srcset=\"https://images-provider.frontiersin.org/api/ipx/w=480&f=webp/https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-g005.jpg\" src=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-g005.jpg\" alt=\"www.frontiersin.org\" id=\"f5\" loading=\"lazy\">\n \u003c/picture>\n\r\n\u003c/a>\r\n\u003cp>\r\n\u003cb>figure 5\u003c/b>. the pathogenic monoallelic \u003cem>de novo ajap1\u003c/em> p.trp183cys variant disrupts presynaptic gbr localization and function. \u003cb>(a)\u003c/b> under normal conditions, postsynaptic ajap1 recruits gb1a/2 receptors to presynaptic terminals via a trans-synaptic interaction with the sd1 of the gb1a subunit. presynaptic gb1a/2s receptors inhibit vgccs (not shown), thereby regulating neurotransmitter release at both gabaergic and glutamatergic synapses. ionotropic gaba or glutamate receptors are depicted in the postsynaptic membrane, along with inward currents (arrow). \u003cb>(b)\u003c/b> in \u003cem>ajap1\u003c/em>\r\n\u003csup>&#x02212;/&#x02212;\u003c/sup> mice, the absence of ajap1 impairs presynaptic gbr recruitment, leading to reduced inhibitory control over gaba and glutamate release, and resulting in deficits in synaptic plasticity. \u003cb>(c)\u003c/b> the pathogenic monoallelic \u003cem>de novo ajap1\u003c/em> p.trp183cys variant, modeled in \u003cem>ajap\u003c/em>\r\n\u003csup>trp183cys/&#x0002b;\u003c/sup> mice, replicates the synaptic dysfunction observed in \u003cem>ajap1\u003c/em>\r\n\u003csup>\r\n\u003cem>&#x02212;/&#x02212;\u003c/em>\r\n\u003c/sup> mice. this variant has a dysfunctional sd1 binding site, thereby impairing presynaptic localization of gbrs. as a result, gbr-mediated inhibition of neurotransmitter release is reduced, leading to deficits in synaptic plasticity and, in affected individuals, to seizures.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"clear\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003ca id=\"h5-4\" name=\"h5-4\">\r\n\u003c/a>\r\n\u003ch3 class=\"pt0\">4.4 \u003cem>pianp\u003c/em> variants\u003c/h3>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb0\">pianp is a single-pass transmembrane protein with sequence homology to ajap1 (\u003ca href=\"#b21\">dinamarca et al., 2019\u003c/a>). like ajap1, it is a primary interaction partner of gbrs and binds to the sd1 domain of the gb1a subunit, albeit with a tenfold higher binding affinity (\u003ca href=\"#b21\">dinamarca et al., 2019\u003c/a>). the sd1-binding sites in pianp and ajap1 share only weak sequence homology, but pianp also contains the conserved tryptophan residue essential for binding. unlike ajap1, pianp lacks dendritic sorting motifs in its c-terminal intracellular domain and is expressed in both axons and dendrites. pianp could therefore interact with gb1a in \u003cem>cis\u003c/em> within axons and in \u003cem>trans\u003c/em> across synapses in dendrites (\u003ca href=\"#f1\">figure 1b\u003c/a>). interestingly, however, pianp cannot compensate for the loss of ajap1 at mossy fiber synapses (\u003ca href=\"#b30\">fruh et al., 2024\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb0\">a case study described a boy with a homozygous nonsense variant in \u003cem>pianp\u003c/em>, who presented with global developmental delay (\u003ca href=\"#b106\">winkler et al., 2020\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b3\">anazi et al., 2017\u003c/a>) (\u003ca href=\"#t5\">table 5\u003c/a>). an additional individual with a heterozygous variant in pianp was reported to exhibit musculoskeletal and nervous system abnormalities (\u003ca href=\"#t5\">table 5\u003c/a>). the synaptic effects of \u003cem>pianp\u003c/em> loss were investigated in \u003cem>pianp\u003c/em> knockout mice, which model the homozygous human condition. electrophysiological recordings revealed a loss of presynaptic gbr-mediated inhibition at hippocampal synapses, suggesting that pianp is required for stabilizing presynaptic gbrs, either in \u003cem>cis\u003c/em> or through a trans-synaptic mechanism, similar to ajap1 (\u003ca href=\"#b106\">winkler et al., 2020\u003c/a>). behavioral phenotyping in mice demonstrated that \u003cem>pianp\u003c/em> deficiency leads to context-dependent increases in anxiety, spatial learning deficits, an altered stress response, severely impaired social interactions, and enhanced repetitive behaviors&#x02014;all characteristic features of an autism spectrum disorder-like phenotype.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003ca id=\"h5-5\" name=\"h5-5\">\r\n\u003c/a>\r\n\u003ch3 class=\"pt0\">4.5 \u003cem>kctd8\u003c/em>, \u003cem>kctd12\u003c/em> and \u003cem>kctd16\u003c/em> variants\u003c/h3>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb0\">kctd8, kctd12, and kctd16 interact with most gbrs in the brain and are considered auxiliary subunits of the receptor (\u003ca href=\"#b84\">schwenk et al., 2010\u003c/a>). they bind to both the receptor and the g protein, regulate the kinetics of the receptor response (\u003ca href=\"#b28\">fritzius et al., 2024\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b96\">turecek et al., 2014\u003c/a>), and also function as scaffolding proteins for effector channels such as vgccs and hcn channels (\u003ca href=\"#b75\">perez-garci et al., 2025\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b94\">trovo et al., 2024\u003c/a>). these roles suggest that dysfunctional kctd proteins could contribute to pathologies associated with gbr dysfunction. gwas have linked kctd proteins to a range of neuropsychiatric and neurological conditions, including asd, bipolar disorder, major depression, alcohol and opioid use disorders, insomnia, dementia, and brain development (\u003ca href=\"#t1\">table 1\u003c/a>). however, to date, no missense variants in \u003cem>kctd\u003c/em> genes have provided causal links to gbr-related pathologies.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003ca id=\"h6\" name=\"h6\">\r\n\u003c/a>\r\n\u003ch2>5 conclusion\u003c/h2>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb15\">early pharmacological studies were instrumental in uncovering potential disease associations and suggesting therapeutic indications for gbr agonists and antagonists. today, advances in genetic and genomic technologies enable the establishment of firm causal links between gene variants and human disease. as a widely adopted diagnostic tool, wes has facilitated the discovery of numerous missense variants in \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em>&#x02014;currently 80 in \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and 433 in \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em>, according to the clinvar database at the time of this review. missense and deletion variants have also been identified in \u003cem>ajap1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>pianp\u003c/em>, two proteins that selectively interact with presynaptic gbrs. recombinant \u003cem>in vitro\u003c/em> assays and mouse models have enabled the causal linking of several missense and deletion variants in \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em>, \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em>, \u003cem>ajap1\u003c/em>, and \u003cem>pianp\u003c/em> to a spectrum of neurodevelopmental disorders, including epileptic encephalopathy, rett-like syndrome, global developmental delay, id, asd, and motor disorders. among these, epilepsy is a frequent condition in individuals with \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> variants, consistent with the increased excitation&#x02013;inhibition ratio and seizure susceptibility observed in gbr-deficient mice. while \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> variants affect both pre- and postsynaptic gbrs, \u003cem>ajap1\u003c/em> variants selectively impair presynaptic gbrs but result in clinical manifestations similar to lof variants in \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> or \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em>. in general, human phenotypes extend and refine insights gained from mouse models carrying equivalent variants. while such models are valuable for dissecting synaptic mechanisms, they have limited predictive power for complex neuropsychiatric and cognitive outcomes. conversely, hyperalgesia&#x02014;a robust phenotype in gbr-deficient mice&#x02014;has not yet been causally linked to any known pathogenic variants in humans.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb15\">a large number of \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> vus in clinvar are found in individuals with phenotypes typically associated with gbr-related disorders, and many of these vus receive high pathogenicity scores from \u003cem>in silico\u003c/em> prediction tools. this suggests that a substantial proportion of currently unclassified variants may, in fact, be disease-causing. functional validation in recombinant assay systems offers a rapid and cost-effective approach to assess the impact of such vus on gbr function. these assays can discriminate between lof and gof effects, thereby facilitating the establishment of mechanistic links between receptor dysfunction and specific disease phenotypes. notably, variants exhibiting similar properties in functional assay systems have been classified under distinct clinical diagnoses&#x02014;for example, epileptic encephalopathy (ee) or rett-like syndromes. this highlights the value of recombinant functional assays in enabling more accurate molecular diagnoses and refining genotype-phenotype correlations in affected individuals. a major bottleneck, however, is the limited availability of such functional platforms in clinical diagnostic settings&#x02014;underscoring the need for scalable, robust assay systems and improved computational tools. promising advances include the use of molecular dynamics simulations, which have been applied to predict constitutively active gbr states and to enhance conventional pathogenicity assessments. in addition, variants in gbr-associated proteins&#x02014;such as syt11, app, and channels including vgccs, hcn, and trpv1&#x02014;may contribute to gbr dysfunction and disease. however, as these proteins either modulate gbr trafficking or act as downstream effectors, their functional impact is challenging to assess using standard recombinant assay systems.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb15\">accurate genetic diagnosis and a mechanistic understanding of disease pathology form the foundation for developing targeted, individualized treatment strategies. in the case of gbrs, a broad pharmacological toolkit is already available, including agonists, inverse agonists, and both positive and negative allosteric modulators. in principle, crispr/cas technologies can be used to rapidly generate mouse models carrying specific, recurrent pathogenic variants&#x02014;such as \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> p.ala567thr&#x02014;providing a powerful platform for testing pharmacological interventions and advancing precision medicine approaches.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003ca id=\"h7\" ## Discussion
early pharmacological studies were instrumental in uncovering potential disease associations and suggesting therapeutic indications for gbr agonists and antagonists. today, advances in genetic and genomic technologies enable the establishment of firm causal links between gene variants and human disease. as a widely adopted diagnostic tool, wes has facilitated the discovery of numerous missense variants in gabbr1 and gabbr2 &#x02014;currently 80 in gabbr1 and 433 in gabbr2 , according to the clinvar database at the time of this review. missense and deletion variants have also been identified in ajap1 and pianp , two proteins that selectively interact with presynaptic gbrs. recombinant in vitro assays and mouse models have enabled the causal linking of several missense and deletion variants in gabbr1 , gabbr2 , ajap1 , and pianp to a spectrum of neurodevelopmental disorders, including epileptic encephalopathy, rett-like syndrome, global developmental delay, id, asd, and motor disorders. among these, epilepsy is a frequent condition in individuals with gabbr1 and gabbr2 variants, consistent with the increased excitation&#x02013;inhibition ratio and seizure susceptibility observed in gbr-deficient mice. while gabbr1 and gabbr2 variants affect both pre- and postsynaptic gbrs, ajap1 variants selectively impair presynaptic gbrs but result in clinical manifestations similar to lof variants in gabbr1 or gabbr2 . in general, human phenotypes extend and refine insights gained from mouse models carrying equivalent variants. while such models are valuable for dissecting synaptic mechanisms, they have limited predictive power for complex neuropsychiatric and cognitive outcomes. conversely, hyperalgesia&#x02014;a robust phenotype in gbr-deficient mice&#x02014;has not yet been causally linked to any known pathogenic variants in humans. a large number of gabbr1 and gabbr2 vus in clinvar are found in individuals with phenotypes typically associated with gbr-related disorders, and many of these vus receive high pathogenicity scores from in silico prediction tools. this suggests that a substantial proportion of currently unclassified variants may, in fact, be disease-causing. functional validation in recombinant assay systems offers a rapid and cost-effective approach to assess the impact of such vus on gbr function. these assays can discriminate between lof and gof effects, thereby facilitating the establishment of mechanistic links between receptor dysfunction and specific disease phenotypes. notably, variants exhibiting similar properties in functional assay systems have been classified under distinct clinical diagnoses&#x02014;for example, epileptic encephalopathy (ee) or rett-like syndromes. this highlights the value of recombinant functional assays in enabling more accurate molecular diagnoses and refining genotype-phenotype correlations in affected individuals. a major bottleneck, however, is the limited availability of such functional platforms in clinical diagnostic settings&#x02014;underscoring the need for scalable, robust assay systems and improved computational tools. promising advances include the use of molecular dynamics simulations, which have been applied to predict constitutively active gbr states and to enhance conventional pathogenicity assessments. in addition, variants in gbr-associated proteins&#x02014;such as syt11, app, and channels including vgccs, hcn, and trpv1&#x02014;may contribute to gbr dysfunction and disease. however, as these proteins either modulate gbr trafficking or act as downstream effectors, their functional impact is challenging to assess using standard recombinant assay systems. accurate genetic diagnosis and a mechanistic understanding of disease pathology form the foundation for developing targeted, individualized treatment strategies. in the case of gbrs, a broad pharmacological toolkit is already available, including agonists, inverse agonists, and both positive and negative allosteric modulators. in principle, crispr/cas technologies can be used to rapidly generate mouse models carrying specific, recurrent pathogenic variants&#x02014;such as gabbr2 p.ala567thr&#x02014;providing a powerful platform for testing pharmacological interventions and advancing precision medicine approaches. author contributions mg: drug effects. indexed in pubmed central (pmc), scopus, web of science (scie), and the doaj, the journal welcomes academic, industrial, and clinical work focused on pharmacology.\u003c/li>\n\u003c/ul>\n\n\u003cp>all submissions to the journal involving natural products, including plant extracts or preparations, must adhere to \u003ci>'the four pillars of ethnopharmacology'\u003c/i> to be considered for peer review, regardless of the specialty section, as a baseline standard for sample characterization. these are a set of mandatory guidelines designed to maintain the scientific, cultural, and ethical integrity of the journal, and describe what the leading journals in the field consider as the basic aspects of good research (full conphymp statement available \u003ca href=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/pharmacology/articles/10.3389/fphar.2022.953205/full\" target=\"_blank\">here\u003c/a>, conphymp statement overview \u003ca href=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/pharmacology/articles/10.3389/fphar.2023.1338710/full\" target=\"_blank\">here\u003c/a>, and ga-tool \u003ca href=\"https://ga-online.org/best-practice/\" target=\"_blank\">here\u003c/a>). please refer to the \u003ca href=\"https://assets.ctfassets.net/41vi7p4898pd/63dcrrxgncg4b1stfayeh8/1b87b9a742b0610ace5b19fd11f62359/four_pillars_ethnopharmacology_2025.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">full version\u003c/a> of these guidelines before submitting a manuscript to the journal.\u003c/p> \n\u003cp>to be considered for publication in frontiers in pharmacology, studies incorporating complementary or alternative medicine must be based on a set of data linked to local or traditional uses that can be evaluated pharmacologically. a clear and plausible set of pharmacological data must be generated in these studies. similarly, the journal endorses protocols including a minimum of 2 cell-lines in vitro as an evidential basis to demonstrate proposed anti-cancer effects in all relevant studies submitted to all specialty sections in the journal.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>isolated data mining studies using disproportionality analyses of databases containing spontaneously reported adverse events, frequently lead to misinterpretation due to various reporting biases, lack of structured control, and insufficient demographic details. presenting such analyses in isolation typically does not yield clinically actionable safety findings without the broader context of a comprehensive signal evaluation. to ensure rigor and relevance, all submissions to the journal must be complemented by a proper systematic review and/or thorough analyses of reported cases, and adhere to the readus-pv guidelines (\u003ca href=\"https://www.equator-network.org/reporting-guidelines/the-reporting-of-a-disproportionality-analysis-for-drug-safety-signal-detection-using-individual-case-safety-reports-in-pharmacovigilance-readus-pv-development-and-statement/\" target=\"_blank\">the reporting of a disproportionality analysis for drug safety signal detection using individual case safety reports in pharmacovigilance\u003c/a>). authors are expected to ensure compliance with the corresponding \u003ca href=\"https://readus-statement.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/readus-checklist.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">checklist\u003c/a> before proceeding with submission to the journal. full publication of the readus-pv guidelines is available \u003ca href=\"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/pmc11116242/pdf/40264_2024_article_1421.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">here\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\n\n\u003cp>frontiers’ journals require that manuscripts primarily comprising computational studies of public data, such as nhanes or mendelian randomization studies, must include appropriate validation. please refer to the \u003ca href=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/guidelines/policies-and-publication-ethics#standards-for-research-methodology:~:text=complaints%20and%20allegations.-,standards%20for%20research%20methodology,-experiments\">frontiers standards for research methodology policy\u003c/a>, for more information. manuscripts not adhering to these standards will not be considered.\u003cp>\n\n\u003cp>further unique criteria for the conception and review of submissions may apply, where appropriate, for individual specialty sections.\u003c/p>\n\n\u003cp>the journal welcomes submissions that support and advance the \u003ca href=\"https://www.globalgoals.org/goals/\" target=\"_blank\">un sustainable development goals\u003c/a> (sdgs), notably the \u003ca href=\"https://www.globalgoals.org/goals/3-good-health-and-well-being/\" target=\"_blank\">sdg 3: good health and well-being\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\n\n\u003cp>manuscripts that focus solely on clinical trials, patient management, or conventional therapies without a focus on pharmacological research are not suitable for publication in this journal. additionally, studies that are purely statistical or predictive in nature, without providing novel insights into pharmacological mechanisms or drug development, are not within the scope of this journal.\u003c/p>\n\n\u003cp>frontiers in pharmacology is committed to advancing developments in the field of pharmacological discoveries by allowing unrestricted access to articles and communicating scientific knowledge to researchers and the public alike, to enable the scientific breakthroughs of the future.\u003c/p>\n\n\u003cb>\u003cp>ethics information\u003c/p>\u003c/b>\n\u003cp>research involving human subjects should comply with the ethical guidelines outlined in the \u003ca href= https://www.wma.net/policies-post/wma-declaration-of-helsinki/” target=”_blank”>world medical association’s declaration of helsinki\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>similarly, authors are required to specify the institutional and national standards adhered to for the care and use of laboratory animals. transparent and accurate href=\"https://nc3rs.org.uk/sites/default/files/2022-01/the%20improve%20guidelines%20%28poster%29.pdf\" target=\"_blank\"> improve\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>extended information on research ethics disorders","2025-07-01t15:51:10.000z","2025-05-23t15:42:40.000z","2025-07-18t00:00:00.000z","2025-10-21t02:29:51.372z","gabab receptors (gbrs) are g protein-coupled receptors that mediate the actions of the inhibitory neurotransmitter gaba in the central nervous system. early pharmacological studies with the gbr agonist baclofen and high-affinity antagonists were instrumental in revealing both pre- and postsynaptic functions of gbrs, establishing their critical role in maintaining the excitation-inhibition balance in the brain and highlighting their potential as therapeutic targets. the molecular cloning of gbr subunits enabled the generation of gbr knock-out mouse models, allowing assignment of distinct functions to pharmacologically indistinguishable receptor subtypes and the establishment of causal links between receptor dysfunction and pathological conditions. advances in high-throughput genomic technologies, particularly whole-exome sequencing, have uncovered hundreds of variants in the genes encoding the gbr subunits, gabbr1 and gabbr2, many of which are linked to neurological and psychiatric disorders. functional characterization of such variants in recombinant assay systems has revealed both gain-of-function (gof) and loss-of-function (lof) mutations, which can now be interpreted in the context of high-resolution structural models of gbr activation. moreover, proteomic studies have revealed that gbrs form macromolecular complexes with a diverse array of auxiliary proteins that modulate their trafficking, localization, signaling kinetics, and ion channel coupling. variants in several of these gbr-associated proteins have now also been linked to human disease, with some shown to selectively impair presynaptic gbr functions in relevant mouse models. here, we review the genetic evidence linking gbr dysfunction to human disease and emphasize the critical role of functional analyses of genetic variants in enhancing diagnostic precision and switzerland\u003c/li>\r\n\u003c/ul>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb15\">gaba\u003csub>b\u003c/sub> receptors (gbrs) are g protein-coupled receptors that mediate the actions of the inhibitory neurotransmitter gaba in the central nervous system. early pharmacological studies with the gbr agonist baclofen and high-affinity antagonists were instrumental in revealing both pre- and postsynaptic functions of gbrs, establishing their critical role in maintaining the excitation-inhibition balance in the brain and highlighting their potential as therapeutic targets. the molecular cloning of gbr subunits enabled the generation of gbr knock-out mouse models, allowing assignment of distinct functions to pharmacologically indistinguishable receptor subtypes and the establishment of causal links between receptor dysfunction and pathological conditions. advances in high-throughput genomic technologies, particularly whole-exome sequencing, have uncovered hundreds of variants in the genes encoding the gbr subunits, \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em>, many of which are linked to neurological and psychiatric disorders. functional characterization of such variants in recombinant assay systems has revealed both gain-of-function (gof) and loss-of-function (lof) mutations, which can now be interpreted in the context of high-resolution structural models of gbr activation. moreover, proteomic studies have revealed that gbrs form macromolecular complexes with a diverse array of auxiliary proteins that modulate their trafficking, localization, signaling kinetics, and ion channel coupling. variants in several of these gbr-associated proteins have now also been linked to human disease, with some shown to selectively impair presynaptic gbr functions in relevant mouse models. here, we review the genetic evidence linking gbr dysfunction to human disease and emphasize the critical role of functional analyses of genetic variants in enhancing diagnostic precision and guiding therapeutic strategies.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"clear\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"journalfulltext\">\r\n\u003ca id=\"h2\" name=\"h2\">\r\n\u003c/a>\r\n\u003ch2>1 introduction\u003c/h2>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb15\">gbrs were first identified in 1980 by norman bowery and colleagues, who used baclofen&#x02014;a muscle relaxant introduced in 1971 for treating spasticity&#x02014;to demonstrate the existence of gaba receptors distinct from the ionotropic gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> receptors (\u003ca href=\"#b11\">bowery et al., 1980\u003c/a>). gbrs are g protein-coupled receptors that modulate neurotransmission at most synapses in the brain and spinal cord (\u003ca href=\"#b33\">gassmann and bettler, 2012\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b76\">pin and bettler, 2016\u003c/a>). they signal through gi/o-type g proteins to regulate adenylyl cyclases, inwardly rectifying potassium (girk or kir3) channels, and voltage-gated calcium channels (vgccs). presynaptic gbrs inhibit the release of both inhibitory and excitatory neurotransmitters by suppressing the activity of vgccs, while postsynaptic gbrs reduce neuronal excitability by opening girk channels, leading to membrane hyperpolarization (\u003ca href=\"#f1\">figure 1a\u003c/a>). through these mechanisms, gbrs modulate a broad spectrum of physiological processes, including synaptic plasticity and the regulation of excitation-inhibition balance within neural networks (\u003ca href=\"#b33\">gassmann and bettler, 2012\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cdiv srcset=\"https://images-provider.frontiersin.org/api/ipx/w=480&f=webp/https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-g001.jpg\" media=\"(max-width: 563px)\">\u003csource type=\"image/webp\" srcset=\"https://images-provider.frontiersin.org/api/ipx/w=370&f=webp/https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-g001.jpg\" media=\"(max-width: 1024px)\">\u003csource type=\"image/webp\" srcset=\"https://images-provider.frontiersin.org/api/ipx/w=290&f=webp/https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-g001.jpg\" media=\"(max-width: 1441px)\">\u003csource type=\"image/webp\" srcset=\"https://images-provider.frontiersin.org/api/ipx/w=410&f=webp/https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-g001.jpg\" media=\"\">\u003csource type=\"image/jpg\" srcset=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-g001.jpg\" media=\"\"> \u003cimg src=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-g001.jpg\" alt=\"www.frontiersin.org\" id=\"f1\" loading=\"lazy\">\n \u003c/picture>\n\r\n\u003c/a>\r\n\u003cp>\r\n\u003cb>figure 1\u003c/b>. macromolecular assemblies and functions of pre- and postsynaptic gbrs. \u003cb>(a)\u003c/b> presynaptic gbrs are assembled with the gb1a subunit and form a signaling complex with vgccs to inhibit neurotransmitter release. the assembly of this presynaptic signaling complex is facilitated by kctd16 and synaptotagmin-11 (syt11). additionally, presynaptic receptors interact with sushi domain (sd)&#x02013;binding proteins via the sd1 of gb1a. postsynaptic gbrs are assembled with the gb1b subunit and activate g protein-coupled girk channels, thereby reducing neuronal excitability. g protein signaling at both pre- and postsynaptic gbrs is modulated by kctd proteins&#x02014;auxiliary subunits that bind to the c-terminal domain of gb2 as well as to the g protein &#x003b2;&#x003b3; subunits. the vftd of gb1 contains the gaba-binding site, while the tmd of gb2 mediates g protein coupling. \u003cb>(b)\u003c/b> the dendritically expressed sd-binding protein ajap1 trans-synaptically recruits gb1a/2 receptors to presynaptic sites. the role of the sd-binding protein pianp in the context of gbrs remains poorly understood. pianp is expressed in both axons and dendrites and may interact with presynaptic gb1a/2 receptors either \u003cem>in cis\u003c/em> or \u003cem>in trans.\u003c/em>\r\n\u003c/p>\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"clear\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb15\">structurally, gbrs are heterodimers composed of gaba\u003csub>b1\u003c/sub> (gb1) and gaba\u003csub>b2\u003c/sub> (gb2) subunits, encoded by the \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> genes, respectively. gb1 subunits contain a c-terminal intracellular retention motif that prevents premature surface expression of the receptor. dimerization with gb2 masks this motif, ensuring that only properly folded and assembled heterodimeric receptor complexes exit the endoplasmic reticulum (\u003ca href=\"#b33\">gassmann and bettler, 2012\u003c/a>). each subunit contains an extracellular venus flytrap domain (vftd), composed of lobe 1 (lb1) and lobe 2 (lb2), a heptahelical transmembrane domain (tmd), and a c-terminal intracellular domain (\u003ca href=\"#f1\">figure 1a\u003c/a>) (\u003ca href=\"#b27\">frangaj and fan, 2018\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b33\">gassmann and bettler, 2012\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b76\">pin and bettler, 2016\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b86\">shaye et al., 2021\u003c/a>). within the heterodimer, gb1 binds gaba and other orthosteric ligands via its vftd, while gb2 engages the g protein through its tmd (\u003ca href=\"#b62\">mao et al., 2020\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b88\">shen et al., 2021\u003c/a>). receptor activation involves conformational changes, including the closure of the gb1 vftd upon agonist binding, which brings the lb2 lobes of both vftds into contact (\u003ca href=\"#b27\">frangaj and fan, 2018\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b33\">gassmann and bettler, 2012\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b76\">pin and bettler, 2016\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b86\">shaye et al., 2021\u003c/a>). this interaction triggers a rearrangement of transmembrane (tm) helix interfaces from tm3-tm5/tm3-tm5 in the inactive state to tm6/tm6 in the active state, forming a shallow pocket for g protein docking at the base of the gb2 tmd. competitive antagonists prevent the closure of the gb1 vftd, while positive allosteric modulators (pams) binding at the tm6 interface stabilize the active state of the receptor (\u003ca href=\"#b35\">geng et al., 2013\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b58\">liu et al., 2021\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b62\">mao et al., 2020\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b86\">shaye et al., 2021\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b88\">shen et al., 2021\u003c/a>). two gb1 isoforms, gb1a and gb1b, are generated from the \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> gene via alternative promoter usage and splicing (\u003ca href=\"#b33\">gassmann and bettler, 2012\u003c/a>). gb1a contains two sushi domains, sd1 and sd2, absent in gb1b (\u003ca href=\"#f1\">figure 1a\u003c/a>). this structural difference does not affect the orthosteric binding site or alter the signaling properties of gb1a/2 and gb1b/2 receptors, which remain pharmacologically indistinguishable. however, mice lacking gb1a exhibit a loss of presynaptic inhibition of vgccs, whereas those lacking gb1b show impaired postsynaptic activation of girk channels. these findings highlight the critical role of the sushi domains in directing gb1a-containing receptors to presynaptic sites (\u003ca href=\"#b33\">gassmann and bettler, 2012\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b101\">vigot et al., 2006\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb15\">gbrs form macromolecular complexes through interactions with proteins that influence receptor localization and signaling (\u003ca href=\"#b21\">dinamarca et al., 2019\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b30\">fruh et al., 2024\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b76\">pin and bettler, 2016\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b84\">schwenk et al., 2010\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b85\">schwenk et al., 2016\u003c/a>). proteomic studies have identified adherens junction-associated protein 1 (ajap1), pilr-associated neural protein (pianp), and potassium channel tetramerization domain-containing proteins&#x02014;kctd8, kctd12, and kctd16&#x02014;as being predominantly or exclusively associated with gbrs (\u003ca href=\"#b21\">dinamarca et al., 2019\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b30\">fruh et al., 2024\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b85\">schwenk et al., 2016\u003c/a>) (\u003ca href=\"#f1\">figure 1a\u003c/a>). ajap1 and pianp interact with the n-terminal sd1 of the presynaptically expressed gb1a subunit (\u003ca href=\"#b21\">dinamarca et al., 2019\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b30\">fruh et al., 2024\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b85\">schwenk et al., 2016\u003c/a>). ajap1 is selectively expressed in dendrites and recruits gbrs to presynaptic sites through a trans-synaptic mechanism (\u003ca href=\"#b21\">dinamarca et al., 2019\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b30\">fruh et al., 2024\u003c/a>) (\u003ca href=\"#f1\">figure 1b\u003c/a>). pianp is expressed in both axons and dendrites, yet its role in the context of gbrs remains poorly understood (\u003ca href=\"#b21\">dinamarca et al., 2019\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b106\">winkler et al., 2020\u003c/a>) (\u003ca href=\"#f1\">figure 1b\u003c/a>). the kctd proteins function as auxiliary subunits of gbrs, interacting with the c-terminal domain of gb2 and the g&#x003b2;&#x003b3; subunits of the g protein, thereby stabilizing the g protein at the receptor (\u003ca href=\"#b28\">fritzius et al., 2024\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b96\">turecek et al., 2014\u003c/a>) (\u003ca href=\"#f1\">figure 1a\u003c/a>). this dual interaction with the receptor and the g protein allows kctd proteins to modulate both the activation and deactivation kinetics of g protein signaling (\u003ca href=\"#b28\">fritzius et al., 2024\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b84\">schwenk et al., 2010\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b96\">turecek et al., 2014\u003c/a>). proteomic analyses have further revealed a broader network of non-exclusive protein interactions with gbrs, including amyloid precursor protein (app) (\u003ca href=\"#b21\">dinamarca et al., 2019\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b78\">rem et al., 2023\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b79\">rice et al., 2019\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b85\">schwenk et al., 2016\u003c/a>), synaptotagmin-11 (syt11) (\u003ca href=\"#b94\">trovo et al., 2024\u003c/a>), hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (hcn) channels (\u003ca href=\"#b75\">perez-garci et al., 2025\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b85\">schwenk et al., 2016\u003c/a>), vgccs (\u003ca href=\"#b85\">schwenk et al., 2016\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b94\">trovo et al., 2024\u003c/a>), and transient receptor potential vanilloid 1 (trpv1) channels (\u003ca href=\"#b40\">hanack et al., 2015\u003c/a>). app is required for efficient axonal trafficking of gbrs to presynaptic release sites (\u003ca href=\"#b21\">dinamarca et al., 2019\u003c/a>), while syt11 promotes the preassembly of the gbr-kctd16-vgcc signaling complex prior to its delivery to the plasma membrane (\u003ca href=\"#b94\">trovo et al., 2024\u003c/a>). consequently, mice lacking either syt11 or app exhibit impaired presynaptic gbr-mediated inhibition of neurotransmitter release (\u003ca href=\"#b21\">dinamarca et al., 2019\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b94\">trovo et al., 2024\u003c/a>). the interaction between hcn channels and gbrs, mediated by kctd16, facilitates hcn channel activation during postsynaptic hyperpolarization, thereby providing a negative feedback mechanism that curtails the duration of inhibition (\u003ca href=\"#b75\">perez-garci et al., 2025\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb15\">consistent with their essential role in the temporal regulation of neuronal activity and the maintenance of excitation-inhibition balance within neural networks, biochemical and pharmacological studies have now established causal links between variants of uncertain significance (vus) in the genes for gbr subunits and associated proteins in broad spectrum of neurodevelopmental disorders. these include neurodevelopmental disorder with language delay and variable cognitive abnormalities (nedlc), neurodevelopmental disorder with poor language and loss of hand skills (ndplhs), developmental and epileptic encephalopathy 59 (dee59), intellectual disability (id), and autism spectrum disorder (asd). in this review, we explore the role of gbrs in human disease, with particular focus on missense and deletion variants that implicate gbr subunits and key interacting proteins&#x02014;ajap1 and pianp&#x02014;in disease pathogenesis.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003ca id=\"h3\" name=\"h3\">\r\n\u003c/a>\r\n\u003ch2>2 expression and autoantibody studies implicating gbrs in disease\u003c/h2>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb15\">early investigations to explore potential links to disease focused on changes in gbr protein and transcript expression in brain tissue from patients. for example, quantitative autoradiography using [\u003csup>3\u003c/sup>h]-gaba or high-affinity gbr antagonists like [\u003csup>3\u003c/sup>h]-cgp62349, along with immunocytochemistry on hippocampal tissue from patients with temporal lobe epilepsy, supported a reduced gbr density compared to postmortem controls (\u003ca href=\"#b68\">munoz et al., 2002\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b77\">princivalle et al., 2002\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b102\">vlachou, 2022\u003c/a>). altered transcript expression levels and redistribution of gbr subunits have also been observed in the postmortem brains of patients with epilepsy, schizophrenia, autism, bipolar disorder, fragile x syndrome, and alzheimer&#x02019;s disease (\u003ca href=\"#b25\">fatemi et al., 2009\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b26\">fatemi et al., 2017\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b46\">iwakiri et al., 2005\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b67\">mudge et al., 2008\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b87\">sheilabi et al., 2018\u003c/a>). although such expression studies have suggested a role for gbrs in disease, their informative value is limited, as they cannot distinguish whether observed changes in receptor protein or transcript levels reflect adaptive responses to the disease or its treatment, or whether they contribute directly to disease pathogenesis.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb15\">compelling evidence for a direct role of gbrs in the etiology of epilepsy comes from studies showing that autoantibodies targeting gbrs may contribute to autoimmune epilepsy by disrupting receptor expression or interfering with receptor signaling (\u003ca href=\"#b55\">lancaster et al., 2010\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b98\">van coevorden-hameete et al., 2019\u003c/a>). notably, autoantibodies against the auxiliary gbr subunit kctd16 have been detected alongside those targeting the gb1 subunit in patients with encephalitis, further implicating gbrs in the pathogenesis of the disease (\u003ca href=\"#b98\">van coevorden-hameete et al., 2019\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\r\n\u003ca id=\"h4\" name=\"h4\">\r\n\u003c/a>\r\n\u003ch2>3 pharmacological implications of gbrs in disease\u003c/h2>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb15\">baclofen (lioresal\u003csup>&#x000ae;\u003c/sup>), a lipophilic analog of &#x003b3;-aminobutyric acid (gaba), was initially developed in the 1960s as an antiepileptic agent (\u003ca href=\"#b97\">urwyler, 2011\u003c/a>). although it proved ineffective for epilepsy, it was approved in 1971 for the treatment of spasticity associated with conditions such as multiple sclerosis and spinal cord injury. in 1980, baclofen was shown to be a selective agonist of gbrs (\u003ca href=\"#b11\">bowery et al., 1980\u003c/a>). baclofen has been explored off-label for various conditions. however, its broader therapeutic application is limited by side effects such as sedation, dizziness, and muscle weakness, as well as by the development of tolerance with prolonged use. notably, baclofen has been studied extensively for the treatment of alcohol dependence and withdrawal. in 2018, it received formal market authorization in france for the management of alcohol use disorders (\u003ca href=\"#b42\">hwa et al., 2014\u003c/a>). gamma-hydroxybutyrate (ghb; xyrem\u003csup>&#x000ae;\u003c/sup>), a partial agonist at gbrs (\u003ca href=\"#b51\">kaupmann et al., 2003\u003c/a>), is approved for the treatment of excessive daytime sleepiness and cataplexy in patients with narcolepsy (\u003ca href=\"#b81\">roth, 2025\u003c/a>). despite its clinical utility, ghb is classified as a schedule i controlled substance in the united states outside approved medical use, due to its potent central nervous system depressant effects and high potential for abuse&#x02014;particularly its involvement in drug-facilitated sexual assault. pams of gbrs provide a more selective therapeutic approach than orthosteric agonists, as they enhance the actions of endogenous gaba by increasing the receptor&#x02019;s affinity and/or efficacy (\u003ca href=\"#b97\">urwyler, 2011\u003c/a>). pams modulate gbrs in a manner that more closely mirrors the receptors&#x02019; endogenous temporal and spatial activation patterns, thereby reducing the risk of adverse effects. pams of gbrs generally do not produce sedation, hypothermia, or muscle relaxation. preclinical studies have demonstrated the therapeutic potential of pams across a range of conditions, including spasticity, epilepsy, depression, anxiety, pain, and substance use disorders (\u003ca href=\"#b7\">bicakci et al., 2022\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b17\">cryan and kaupmann, 2005\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b42\">hwa et al., 2014\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b47\">jacobson and cryan, 2008\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b48\">kalinichev et al., 2017\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b49\">kannampalli et al., 2017\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b60\">lopes et al., 2015\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b66\">minere et al., 2024\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b102\">vlachou, 2022\u003c/a>). although baclofen and pams demonstrate that enhancing gbr activity can ameliorate pathological conditions, their therapeutic efficacy alone does not necessarily establish gbr hypofunction as the primary cause of these diseases. instead, gbr agonists and pams are generally expected to be beneficial in disorders characterized by an increased excitation-inhibition ratio within neural networks. nevertheless, the therapeutic effects of these compounds are often observed in conditions that mirror phenotypes seen in gbr-deficient mice (see 4.1), providing supportive evidence for a causal link between gbr hypofunction and disease pathophysiology. the low-affinity gbr antagonist sgs742 (cgp36742) has demonstrated cognition-enhancing effects in both preclinical and clinical settings (\u003ca href=\"#b29\">froestl et al., 2004\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b102\">vlachou, 2022\u003c/a>). however, broader exploration of gbr antagonists in disease models has been constrained by their proconvulsant liability (\u003ca href=\"#b91\">teichgraber et al., 2009\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b99\">vergnes et al., 1997\u003c/a>), which causally implicates gbr hypofunction in seizure-related hyperexcitability.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003ca id=\"h5\" name=\"h5\">\r\n\u003c/a>\r\n\u003ch2>4 genetic links between gbrs and disease\u003c/h2>\r\n\u003ca id=\"h5-1\" name=\"h5-1\">\r\n\u003c/a>\r\n\u003ch3 class=\"pt0\">4.1 gbr-deficient mice\u003c/h3>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb0\">the cloning of gbr cdnas (\u003ca href=\"#b64\">marshall et al., 1999\u003c/a>) made it possible to genetically ablate individual receptor subunits in mice, thereby establishing a direct genetic link between gbr dysfunction and disease. due to the obligate heterodimeric nature of gbrs, knockout of either the gb1 subunit (comprising the gb1a and gb1b isoforms) or the gb2 subunit results in similar synaptic deficits and pathologies (\u003ca href=\"#b33\">gassmann and bettler, 2012\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b34\">gassmann et al., 2004\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b83\">schuler et al., 2001\u003c/a>), including complete loss of both pre- and postsynaptic gbr responses, spontaneous seizures, increased susceptibility to induced seizures, cognitive impairments, hyperactivity, altered circadian activity, and hyperalgesia (\u003ca href=\"#b34\">gassmann et al., 2004\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b83\">schuler et al., 2001\u003c/a>). the occurrence of seizures in gb1 and gb2 knockout mice supports findings from antagonist studies and highlights the key role of gbrs in maintaining the excitation&#x02013;inhibition balance in the brain through inhibitory signaling. mice with a heterozygous deletion of the gb1 or gb2 subunits have not been systematically analyzed; however, available data suggest that heterozygous gb1-deficient mice exhibit only mild functional and behavioral deficits (\u003ca href=\"#b51\">kaupmann et al., 2003\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b83\">schuler et al., 2001\u003c/a>). selective ablation of the gb1a subunit abolishes presynaptic gbr-mediated inhibition of neurotransmitter release, while deletion of the gb1b subunit disrupts postsynaptic inhibition through girk channels (\u003ca href=\"#b101\">vigot et al., 2006\u003c/a>). notably, only gb1a-deficient but not gb1b-deficient mice exhibit a proconvulsive phenotype (\u003ca href=\"#b101\">vigot et al., 2006\u003c/a>), highlighting the critical role of presynaptic gbrs in limiting glutamate release and preventing excessive excitation, hypersynchronous network activity, and seizure generation. similarly, gb1a-deficient mice show pronounced impairments in learning and memory, likely due to disinhibited glutamate release and subsequent saturation of synaptic plasticity mechanisms (\u003ca href=\"#b101\">vigot et al., 2006\u003c/a>). in comparison, gb1b-deficient mice display milder phenotypes, including hyperactivity, disrupted circadian cycles, spatial memory deficits, and impaired fear conditioning, a form of associative learning (\u003ca href=\"#b33\">gassmann and bettler, 2012\u003c/a>). while the therapeutic benefits of baclofen and pams largely align with disease phenotypes observed in gbr-deficient mice, the cognition-enhancing effects of the gbr antagonist sgs742 (\u003ca href=\"#b29\">froestl et al., 2004\u003c/a>) appear at odds with the pronounced learning and memory deficits reported in gbr-deficient mouse models.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003ca id=\"h5-2\" name=\"h5-2\">\r\n\u003c/a>\r\n\u003ch3 class=\"pt0\">4.2 pathogenic \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> variants in humans\u003c/h3>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb0\">genetic and genomic technologies provide powerful tools for identifying variants in \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> that may predispose individuals to disease or directly contribute its pathogenesis. given the broad expression of gbrs throughout the central nervous system, and the diverse pathologies observed in gbr-deficient mice, genetic variants that impair receptor function are likely to contribute to disease (\u003ca href=\"#b33\">gassmann and bettler, 2012\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b76\">pin and bettler, 2016\u003c/a>). genome-wide association studies (gwas catalog, \u003ca href=\"https://www.ebi.ac.uk/gwintellectualdisabilityas/\">https://www.ebi.ac.uk/gw intellectual disability as/\u003c/a>) have identified single nucleotide polymorphisms and other genetic variants in \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> that are associated with schizophrenia, anxiety and depression/mood disorders, autism spectrum disorder (asd), post-traumatic stress disorder, alcohol use disorder, insomnia, alzheimer&#x02019;s disease, and pain (\u003ca href=\"#t1\">table 1\u003c/a>). based on statistical significance and replication across independent cohorts, the strongest genetic associations have been identified for depression and schizophrenia. however, since all gwas-associated variants in \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> reside in non-coding regions, their impact on gbr function remains unclear. non-coding variants are thought to influence disease by modulating gene expression or alternative splicing of transcript isoforms. their regulatory effects are often modest and cell-type specific, which further complicates the functional validation of disease-associated variants (\u003ca href=\"#b32\">gallagher and chen-plotkin, 2018\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b104\">wainberg et al., 2022\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"imageheaders\">table 1\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"figuredesc\">\r\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-t001.jpg\" name=\"table1\" target=\"_blank\">\r\n\n media=\"\">\u003csource type=\"image/jpg\" srcset=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-t001.jpg\" media=\"\"> \u003cimg src=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-t001.jpg\" alt=\"www.frontiersin.org\" id=\"t1\" loading=\"lazy\">\n \u003c/picture>\n\r\n\u003c/a>\r\n\u003cp>\r\n\u003cb>table 1\u003c/b>. gwas implicating gbrs in human disease.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"clear\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb0\">in contrast to non-coding gwas variants, missense variants identified through whole-exome sequencing (wes) in affected individuals offer a more direct and potentially causal link to disease. \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> are classified as haploinsufficient genes, as indicated by their lof intolerance (pli) scores of 1 in the gnomad database (\u003ca href=\"https://gnomad.broadinstitute.org/\">https://gnomad.broadinstitute.org/\u003c/a>), indicating strong selective pressure against protein-truncating variants. in contrast, mouse models with heterozygous deletion of \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> exhibit only mild functional or behavioral deficits (\u003ca href=\"#b51\">kaupmann et al., 2003\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b83\">schuler et al., 2001\u003c/a>), suggesting species-specific differences in dosage sensitivity or compensatory mechanisms. both genes also exhibit significant constraint against missense variation, with missense z-scores of 5.54 (\u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em>) and 4.11 (\u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em>) in gnomad, suggesting that protein-altering mutations are generally not well tolerated and are more likely to be deleterious and potentially disease-causing. clinvar (\u003ca href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/clinvar/\">https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/clinvar/\u003c/a>), a database documenting human genetic variants and their clinical significance, reports 80 missense variants in \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and 433 in \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> (\u003ca href=\"#f2\">figure 2\u003c/a>). among these, seven monoallelic \u003cem>de novo\u003c/em> variants in \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and fourteen in \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> are classified as pathogenic or likely pathogenic. additional variants with strong evidence of pathogenicity have been reported in the literature but have not yet been included into clinvar. these variants are listed in \u003ca href=\"#t2\">table 2\u003c/a> (\u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em>) and \u003ca href=\"#t3\">table 3\u003c/a> (\u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em>), and have been mapped onto the structural model of gbrs (\u003ca href=\"#f3\">figure 3\u003c/a>). the missense tolerance ratio (mtr) provides a codon-level measure of selective constraint derived from human population sequencing data (\u003ca href=\"#b93\">traynelis et al., 2017\u003c/a>). many, though not all, pathogenic variants in \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> cluster in regions with low mtr scores, consistent with strong purifying selection against amino acid substitutions in these regions (\u003ca href=\"#f2\">figure 2\u003c/a>). due to limited functional validation and incomplete clinical annotation, most missense variants in these genes are currently classified as vus (\u003ca href=\"#b72\">nykamp et al., 2017\u003c/a>). nonetheless, several of these vus have been identified in individuals with phenotypes consistent with gbr-related disorders (\u003ca href=\"#f2\">figure 2\u003c/a>). notably, many of these vus are located in low-mtr regions, particularly within \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em>, supporting that they may be pathogenic and warrant further investigation.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"imageheaders\">figure class=\"dottedline\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cp class=\"mb0\">several algorithms have been developed to predict the pathogenicity of single nucleotide variants (\u003ca href=\"#b61\">macarthur et al., 2014\u003c/a>). these algorithms are used in conjunction with variant frequency data from case cohorts and reference population databases, such as gnomad, bravo, and regeneron (\u003ca href=\"#b50\">karczewski et al., 2020\u003c/a>). to further assess the potential pathogenicity of \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> vus associated with gbr-related disorders, we used three \u003cem>in silico\u003c/em> prediction tools: revel (\u003ca href=\"#b44\">ioannidis et al., 2016\u003c/a>), cadd (\u003ca href=\"#b53\">kircher et al., 2014\u003c/a>), and alphamissense (\u003ca href=\"#b16\">cheng et al., 2023\u003c/a>). scores for revel, cadd and alphamissense were obtained from the dbnsfp database (\u003ca href=\"https://www.dbnsfp.org/\">https://www.dbnsfp.org/\u003c/a>) and compared to those of known pathogenic variants (\u003ca href=\"#f4\">figure 4\u003c/a>). the results show that all three tools reliably classify the majority of known pathogenic variants as deleterious. notably, many \u003cem>gabbr1\u003c/em> and \u003cem>gabbr2\u003c/em> vus linked to gbr-related disorders also received high pathogenicity scores, suggesting they may be disease-causing.\u003c/p>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\r\n\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"imageheaders\">figure 4\u003c/div>\r\n\u003cdiv class=\"figuredesc\">\r\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1634128/fphar-16-1634128-html-r1/image_m/fphar-16-1634128-g004.jpg\" name=\"figure4\" target=\"_blank\">\r\n\n \u003cpicture>\n \u003csource type=\"image/webp\"
